Authors: Ennejjai I.; Ariss A.; Mabrouki J.; Fouad Y.; Alabdultif A.; Chaganti R.; Eddine K.S.; Lamjid A.; Ziti S.
Author full names: Ennejjai, Imane (58475279400); Ariss, Anass (58475757400); Mabrouki, Jamal (57207990984); Fouad, Yasser (6603123645); Alabdultif, Abdulatif (55387649900); Chaganti, Rajasekhar (57223696496); Eddine, Karima Salah (59346861900); Lamjid, Asmaa (58475597500); Ziti, Soumia (55999104600)
Title: An Artificial intelligence Approach to Fake News Detection in the Context of the Morocco Earthquake; [Un enfoque de inteligencia artificial para la detección de noticias falsas en el contexto del terremoto de Marruecos]
Source title: Data and Metadata
Abstract: The catastrophic earthquake that struck Morocco on September 8, 2023, garnered significant media coverage, leading to the swift dissemination of information across various social media and online plat-forms. However, the heightened visibility also gave rise to a surge in fake news, presenting formidable challenges to the efficient distribution of accurate information crucial for effective crisis management. This paper introduces an innovative approach to detection by integrating Natural language processing, bidirectional long-term memory (Bi-LSTM), convolutional neural network (CNN), and hierarchical attention network (HAN) models within the context of this seismic event. Leveraging advanced machine learning,deep learning, and data analysis techniques, we have devised a sophisticated fake news detection model capable of precisely identifying and categorizing misleading information. The amal gamation of these models enhances the accuracy and efficiency of our system, addressing the pressing need for reliable information amidst the chaos of a crisis. © 2024, Editorial Salud, Ciencia y Tecnologia. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Deep Learning Models; Fake news; information; Information Verification; Machine Learning; Natural Language Processing; Social Media
Open Access: All Open Access; Hybrid Gold Open Access

Authors: Kumar K.J.; Shreya K.; Divakarla L.P.; Nair P.C.; Sampath N.
Author full names: Kumar, Kanderi Johith (59353788100); Shreya, Kuthati (59353788200); Divakarla, Lasya Priya (59353363000); Nair, Priyanka C. (57061714500); Sampath, Nalini (56880159700)
Title: Interpretable AI Insights in Fake News Detection: A Comparative Analysis of CNN and LSTM
Source title: 2024 15th International Conference on Computing Communication and Networking Technologies, ICCCNT 2024
Abstract: One of the major concerns in today's world is fake news when the majority of people spend most of their time online on social media. People come across various fake news and false information. It is important to acknowledge how such fake news spreads, and it must be prevented. This project combines text processing with the utilization of relevant machine learning techniques, like categorization based on various text features. The model has undergone training using both traditional machine learning algorithms and deep learning techniques, including Logistic Regression, Decision Tree Classifier, Naïve Bayes Classifier, Support Vector Machine (SVM), Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM), and Convolutional Neural Network (CNN). Logistic Regression and CNN have exhibited the highest model accuracy, achieving 95%. Evaluations have been conducted to make comparisons about the efficacy of the machine learning and deep learning approaches utilized. Explainability techniques like Local Interpretable Model Agnostic Explanations (LIME) have been applied to discern the keywords influencing the classification of data into fake or genuine categories.  © 2024 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Explainable AI Techniques (XAI); Fake News; Text Classification; TFIDF Vectorization; Word Embeddings

Authors: Akash; Singh A.; Chandra M.; Kansal V.; Prakash S.
Author full names: Akash (59222300500); Singh, Abhishek (57199212396); Chandra, Manik (57192682193); Kansal, Vineet (56785732600); Prakash, Shiv (57210508645)
Title: An Efficient Model for Fake News Detection Using Transformer
Source title: International Conference on Parallel, Distributed and Grid Computing, PDGC
Abstract: The public discourse is seriously threatened by the massive circulation of false information via social media and other platforms. This study investigates the potential of transformer models to effectively identify fake news, comparing their performance to mores Deep Learning (DL) and Machine Learning (ML) approaches. While DL and ML models have shown promise in this domain, they often struggle to capture the nuances of language context. Transformers, a more recent advancement indeep learning, excel at understanding the contextual relationships within text. By training transformer models on real-world datasets and evaluating their accuracy in identifying fake news, The objective of this study is to aid in the advancement of false news identification systems that are more dependable and precise. Through a critical analysis of transformer models in comparison to existing techniques, this study seeks to pave the way for future advancements in natural language processing (NLP) and the creation of a more trustworthy online information ecosystem. © 2024 IEEE.
Author Keywords: as well as the detection of false information; Deep learning; Machine learning; NLP; Sentiment Analysis; Transformers

Authors: Shah N.; Mitalia N.; Dhanare R.
Author full names: Shah, Nirmit (59251373100); Mitalia, Niraj (59251349900); Dhanare, Ritesh (57205029503)
Title: Enhancing the Precision and Efficiency of Fake News Prediction: A Comprehensive Review
Source title: Proceedings - 2024 3rd International Conference on Sentiment Analysis and Deep Learning, ICSADL 2024
Abstract: In the digital age, fake news affects public opinion, democracy, and society. The need for efficient and reliable false news detection tools has grown as misinformation spreads swiftly online. This paper reviews recent research on efficient and accurate false news detecting methods. The review begins by describing fake news and its possible effects on society. To reduce misinformation's damage, it stresses prompt and accurate identification. Manual fact-checking and human moderation are critiqued for their inability to handle the size and speed of misinformation. Thus, researchers use computational approaches and machine learning to solve these problems. The research addresses fake news detection using NLP, sentiment analysis, and topic modelling. NLP extracts contextual and linguistic cues, whereas sentiment analysis identifies emotionally manipulative content. Topic modelling helps identify bogus news patterns and themes. The review also examines how recurrent neural networks (RNN s) and transformer-based architectures might detect bogus news. These models have captured complicated textual patterns and advanced false news detection systems. This study emphasizes using varied datasets to train and test false news detection methods. It stresses the importance of representative data for model generalization and robustness and the difficulties of getting reliable labelled datasets. This research study also sheds light on false news detection model development. It emphasizes on computational methods, machine learning, and deep learning to combat misinformation. The study guides researchers and practitioners in developing creative ways to identify fake news quickly and accurately, creating a more educated and resilient digital society. © 2024 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Fake News; Natural Language Processing; Recurrent Neural Networks; Sentiment Analysis

Authors: Madhumitha M.; Kunguma Akshatra M.; Tejashri J.; Jerin Mahibha C.
Author full names: Madhumitha, M. (58886977100); Kunguma Akshatra, M. (58977153700); Tejashri, J. (58977122500); Jerin Mahibha, C. (57879291400)
Title: TechWhiz@DravidianLangTech 2024: Fake News Detection Using Deep Learning Models
Source title: DravidianLangTech 2024 - 4th Workshop on Speech, Vision, and Language Technologies for Dravidian Languages, Proceedings of the Workshop
Abstract: The ever-evolving landscape of online social media has initiated a transformative phase in communication, presenting unprecedented opportunities alongside inherent challenges. The pervasive issue of false information, commonly termed fake news, has emerged as a significant concern within these dynamic platforms. This study delves into the domain of Fake News Detection, with a specific focus on Malayalam. Utilizing advanced transformer models like mBERT, ALBERT, and XMLRoBERTa, our research proficiently classifies social media text into original or fake categories. Notably, our proposed model achieved commendable results, securing a rank of 3 in Task 1 with macro F1 scores of 0.84 using mBERT, 0.56 using ALBERT, and 0.84 using XMLRoBERTa. In Task 2, the XMLRoBERTa model excelled with a rank of 12, attaining a macro F1 score of 0.21, while mBERT and BERT achieved scores of 0.16 and 0.11, respectively. This research aims to develop robust systems capable of discerning authentic from deceptive content, a crucial endeavor in maintaining information reliability on social media platforms amid the rampant spread of misinformation. © 2024 Association for Computational Linguistics.

Authors: Sowmya H.K.; Anandhi R.J.
Title: Comparative Analysis of Deep Learning Techniques for Fake News Detection
Source title: Proceedings of the 2024 3rd Edition of IEEE Delhi Section Flagship Conference, DELCON 2024
Abstract: The proliferation of fake news has been accelerated by the growth of social media and online news outlets, which poses serious risks to social harmony, political stability, and public confidence. The research examines and compares various deep learning techniques, including Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks, and the Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers (BERT) model, to detect fake news. It assesses the effectiveness of these models using a sizable dataset of news reports with authenticity and falsity labels. Important performance parameters including recall, accuracy, precision, and F1-score are considered for analysis. The outcomes show that BERT networks perform better than CNN and LSTM models, with 98.17% accuracy and 98.0% F1-score. The work demonstrates how well BERT captures intricate semantic linkages in text, which makes it a potent instrument for identifying false news. It also offers insights for further research in this area and highlights the power of sophisticated deep learning approaches in improving the effectiveness of false news detection systems.  © 2024 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers (BERT); Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN); Deep learning; Fake news; Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM)

Authors: Abdedaiem A.; Dahou A.H.; Cheragui M.A.; Mathiak B.
Author full names: Abdedaiem, Amin (58634405200); Dahou, Abdelhalim Hafedh (57889862400); Cheragui, Mohamed Amine (55994821300); Mathiak, Brigitte (9942026800)
Title: FASSILA: A Corpus for Algerian Dialect Fake News Detection and Sentiment Analysis
Source title: Procedia Computer Science
Abstract: In the context of low-resource languages, the Algerian dialect (AD) faces challenges due to the absence of annotated corpora, hindering its effective processing, notably in Machine Learning (ML) applications reliant on corpora for training and assessment. This study outlines the development process of a specialized corpus for Fake News (FN) detection and sentiment analysis (SA) in AD called FASSILA. This corpus comprises 10,087 sentences, encompassing over 19,497 unique words in AD, addresses the language's significant lack of linguistic resources, and covers seven distinct domains. We propose an FN detection and SA annotation scheme detailing the data collection, cleaning, and labeling. The remarkable Inter-Annotator Agreement indicates that the annotation scheme produces high-quality and consistent annotations. Subsequent classification experiments using BERT-based and ML models are presented, demonstrating promising results and highlighting avenues for further research. The dataset is currently freely available to facilitate future advancements in the field. © 2024 The Authors. Published by Elsevier B.V.
Author Keywords: Algerian Dialect; Corpus; Deep learning; Fake News; LLMs; Machine learning; Sentiment Analysis
Open Access: All Open Access; Gold Open Access

Issues and Challenges Involved in Robotic Forensics; unmasking the Vulnerabilities: A Deep Dive into the Security Threat Landscape of Humanoid Robots; review of Cyber-Physical System-Based Security Datasets for Learning-Based Intrusion Detection Systems; survey and Analysis of Intrusion Detection Frameworks for Cyber-Physical Systems: A Comprehensive Study; enhancing IoT Security Through Deep Learning: A Comprehensive Study.

Authors: Brinda B.M.; Rajan C.; Geetha K.
Title: Detecting Evolving Fake News in Social Media by Leveraging Heterogeneous Deep Learning Model
Source title: 2nd IEEE International Conference on Advances in Information Technology, ICAIT 2024 - Proceedings
Abstract: A recent study revealed that fake articles spread considerably faster than factual content on Twitter, specifically at a 70% higher rate of retweets and reaching the first 1,500 users six times faster. This highlights the urgent need for scalable automated detection solutions to combat the pervasive threat of fake news online. While machine learning methods often rely solely on semantic text analysis, evolving fake news campaigns mimic genuine news, employing tactics like bot networks and sophisticated language imitation. This renders text-based meth- ods increasingly vulnerable. To address this challenge,we propose a heterogeneous deep learning model that incorporates richer information beyond text, specifically dissemination structure features from social networks. These features capture aspects like user interactions, sharing patterns, and network topology, providing valuable insights into the spread of information. Our model leverages the sentiment and affects the enriched Alt dataset for text analysis. Instead of using a popular language model called BERT, we explore alternative pre-trained language models like the Sentence Transformer, which focuses on capturing con- textual sentence embeddings, or the Universal Language Model (ULMFiT), which excels at understanding semantic relationships within text. Additionally, we consider spaCy, a versatile NLP library offering similar functionalities for text processing and feature extraction. While The Quint Dataset Challenge Dataset lacks sentiment annotations, it could be a potential alternative to Alt depending on research goals. This network-aware approach achieves an impressive 95.27% accuracy on The Boom Live dataset and demonstrates generalizability to The Quint dataset with 92.1% accuracy, highlighting its effectiveness in combatting evolving fake news tactics. © 2024 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Deep learning model; Fake news detection; Heterogeneous network features; Pre-trained language models; Sentiment analysis; Social networks

Authors: Zhang W.; Alzahrani A.I.; Lee M.Y.
Author full names: Zhang, Wei (59413987000); Alzahrani, Ahmed Ibrahim (54912750300); Lee, Mi Young (55902262800)
Title: Fake News Detection in Large-Scale Social Network with Generalized Bayesian Classification
Source title: Mobile Networks and Applications
Abstract: Fake news in large-scale social networks is relatively rare, resulting in poor detection performance of deep learning method without sufficient samples. Meantime, false information comes from various sources and forms in large-scale social networks, which increases the difficulty of detection by simple Bayesian decision. Therefore, a method for detecting fake news in large-scale social networks based on a generalized Bayesian classifier is proposed. By using web crawlers to collect news in social network from multiple platforms such as entertainment, education, and medical diseases, and employing the HITS (Hyperlink-Induced Topic Search) algorithm to analyze webpage links, the accuracy of webpage target data retrieval is improved. A network data cleaning function is utilized to remove redundant and cluttered data from social network. A multi-modal Transformer model is employed to extract fusion features of text and image from large-scale social network data. By optimizing the Bayesian classifier using a greedy selection algorithm, a generalized Bayesian classifier is obtained. The extracted features of fake news from social networks are used as inputs to the generalized Bayesian classifier to obtain the prior probability of fake news in social networks. Based on this prior probability, evidence factors that meet the conditions of fake news in large-scale social networks are obtained. By evaluating the numerical values of these evidence factors, the classification and detection of fake news in large-scale social networks are achieved. Experimental results show that the maximum KL divergence value of the proposed method is 0.01, and the maximum Gini coefficient value is 0.1, indicating excellent performance in information cleaning and feature extraction. The maximum number of false positive results is only one sample, demonstrating its ability to accurately detect Fake News in social networks. © The Author(s), under exclusive licence to Springer Science+Business Media, LLC, part of Springer Nature 2024.
Author Keywords: Fake News; Generalized Bayesian classifier; Greedy algorithm; Large-scale Network; Social Network

Authors: Li F.; Zhang H.; Lian Z.; Wang S.
Title: Fake News Detection Based on Contrast Learning and Cascading Attention
Source title: Proceedings - 2024 IEEE Cyber Science and Technology Congress, CyberSciTech 2024
Abstract: Deepfake is a face image tampering technology based on deep learning. Today's deepfake video has been difficult to distinguish the authenticity by the naked eye. While this technology has brought many positive applications, these fake videos also pose a huge potential threat to our society, such as being used to create fake news and pornographic videos. Therefore, it is necessary to find a method to identify these fake videos. At present, the commonly used detection methods are based on feature information of single frame. The performance of these methods often depends on the selected dataset, and generalizes poorly across different datasets. At the same time, their detection performance on highly compressed video drops significantly. Aiming at the above problems, this paper proposes a method to detect deep face forgery videos based on rPPG signal. This method improves generalization performance by using the inherent physiological features of the human body for fake detection. At the same time, the performance in detecting highly compressed video is improved by using a green single-channel based signal extraction method. The experimental results show that the method proposed in this paper can effectively detect the fake videos generated by a variety of forgery methods, and shows good generalization. At the same time, the detection performance for highly compressed video is significantly better than many current detection methods. © 2024 IEEE.
Author Keywords: deep face forgery; deep learning; rPPG; video detection

Authors: Adaji I.; Okpanachi L.O.
Author full names: Adaji, Ifeoma (57133126700); Okpanachi, Linda O. (58813930800)
Title: Detecting Fake News Spreaders on Social Media Using Posts Content Versus Profile Information
Source title: Proceedings - 2024 IEEE International Conference on Big Data, BigData 2024
Abstract: The rapid spread of misinformation on social media platforms poses significant societal challenges, underscoring the need for effective methods to detect fake news spreaders. While many studies combine textual and user profile features for this task, the individual impact of these attributes remains unclear, raising questions about how each feature independently influences model performance. This study evaluates the effectiveness of textual data and user profile information in detecting fake news spreaders. By utilizing the Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (BiLSTM) model on the TruthSeeker dataset, this study assesses the individual contribution of each feature and analyzes the effect of combining them on model accuracy. Additionally, the role of optimization techniques, such as L2 regularization and early stopping, in improving detection performance was investigated. The results indicate that textual data alone is highly effective (achieving an accuracy of 97.78%) in distinguishing between real and fake news, while the inclusion of user profile data (97.61%) does not significantly enhance model performance. Furthermore, models using only user profile data exhibited accuracy between 55% and 64%, highlighting the limited predictive power of this feature set alone. © 2024 IEEE.
Author Keywords: BiLSTM Model; Deep Learning; Fake News Detection; Fake News Spreaders; Machine Learning; Social Media Analysis; Textual Data; User Profile Data

Authors: Srivastav A.K.; Ranga V.; Vishwakarma D.K.
Author full names: Srivastav, Anup Kumar (59703276900); Ranga, Virender (55599423900); Vishwakarma, Dinesh Kumar (56711360100)
Title: Machine Learning and Deep Learning in Fake News Detection: An In-Depth Review
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE 2024 1st International Conference on Advances in Computing, Communication and Networking, ICAC2N 2024
Abstract: Fake news has emerged as a severe problem in the realm of social media and the internet at large. Hence, with the loads of information created daily related to politics, mainly together with education, it becomes impractical for human beings to be able to verify manually, and automated fact-checking techniques are most essential in handling this information overload. Research reveals that deep learning models, such as LSTM and BERT, outperform most traditional machine learning techniques, including Support Vector Machine and Naive Bayes, which can achieve an average accuracy of 94.21%, while the former is good in semantic and long-range dependency. These methods crave some fundamental textual properties and NLP techniques such as TF-IDF, word embedding's, and stylistic features to function with good efficacy. Ensemble methods combine multiple classifiers to harness the power of several different classifiers in improving detection accuracy. Although challenged by the lack of labeled data in training these accurate models because it is difficult to distinguish fake content, context-specific analysis is required. Some studies have suggested semi-supervised learning and incorporation of user profile information for better accuracy. This is evident from the fact that deep learning techniques are far superior in the task of fake news detection among various models. However, challenges are always there. Future work might focus on developing robust models to manage the dynamic nature of false news, as well as expanding the variety of datasets and feature extraction techniques. © 2024 IEEE.

Authors: Alguttar A.A.; Shaaban O.A.; Yildirim R.
Author full names: Alguttar, Abubaker A. (58726212200); Shaaban, Osama A. (58725046700); Yildirim, Remzi (7003601363)
Title: Optimized Fake News Classification: Leveraging Ensembles Learning and Parameter Tuning in Machine and Deep Learning Methods
Source title: Applied Artificial Intelligence
Abstract: The proliferation of misinformation across various domains necessitates robust detection mechanisms. With its ability to analyze vast datasets, machine learning emerges as a powerful tool. This research aims to explore fake news detection and emphasize the crucial role of preprocessing techniques. In addition to using individual models for training like SVMs, Logistic Regression, and LSTMs, we investigated the combined power of these methods through Stacking and Delegation. This paper analyzes frequently used preprocessing techniques like counter-vectorizer and TF-IDF to understand their impact on detection effectiveness. This is also aligned with the United Nations SDG 16, which seeks to promote informed decision-making by fighting against misinformation. The outcomes of this study underscored the significance of preprocessing steps for optimal classification performance. The ensemble methods consistently excelled, particularly with the probability-based stacking, achieving an AUC of 0.9394 and 0.9509 along with F1 Scores of 0.956248 and 0.945644. On the other hand, the delegation strategies also emerged as solid alternatives, with delegation (iterated) reaching AUCs of 0.9280 and 0.9477. The findings of this study confirm the efficacy of ensemble techniques and delegation for effective fake news detection. This study offers insights into model selection and optimization. © 2024 The Author(s). Published with license by Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.
Open Access: All Open Access; Gold Open Access

Authors: Tufchi S.; Yadav A.; Ahmed T.
Author full names: Tufchi, Shivani (58184371600); Yadav, Ashima (57202991991); Ahmed, Tanveer (57213239734)
Title: Advanced Multi-Model Approach for Robust Image-Based Fake News Detection: A Comparative Study of Different Image Models
Source title: 2024 15th International Conference on Computing Communication and Networking Technologies, ICCCNT 2024
Abstract: Fake news that is propagated in this era is a very important issue. It has widespread effects on denorphising the public trust, transmitting wrong or false information, damaging the stability of society as whole. These type of news are shared easily in a short time, which is seen in the social media platforms. There can be misinformation and manipulation of a massive number of people. To address this issue, we primarily focused on the fake news detections with deep learning models. In this work we investigate using five most image models which are Swin, ConvNeXt, VGG-19, BEiT and ResNet-50, which can be helpful in linear or non-linear ways for fake news detections, it can be a feature extraction process also, which might help in improving the detection performances of anti-fake news detectors and it also can be helpful to see the data easily and introduce experiments that might improve the robustness. Here, we are reporting this methodology to detect the fake news using these five image models for extracting the features and feeding the extracted features into the multi-layer perceptron (MLP) to classify the given news is either real as fake or not. We performed experiments using the IFND dataset and tested our multi-faceted feature extraction strategy which has proven to be effective. Each model has its own potential and it makes a difference in itself, producing it's unique manufactured model and it could represents it's own diverse visually rich representations which can be very useful in discriminating fake news. To show the proof of concept, improving the impicity of discriminating towards detecting fake news by using different image models, we extensively performed a comparison analysis for the state-of-the-art image models. By these extensive analysis, we attained the test accuracy of 88.66% on using Convnext-Tiny architecture and 91% F1 score while using the swin transformer architecture. The extensive analysis provides the relative advantages and disadvantages of the image models. This work gives a solid and powerful approach to tackle the spreading of fake news and sets a new benchmark to the research community in future research related to fake news detection. The work demonstrates the robust and effective fake news detection methods for precise information diffusion. © 2024 IEEE.
Author Keywords: BEiT; CNN; Convnext; IFND; Image; ResNet50; VGG-19; Vision Transformer

Authors: Sreekar Datta K.S.; Narasimha Naidu G.; Abhishek S.; Anjali T.
Author full names: Sreekar Datta, K.S. (59074536900); Narasimha Naidu, G. (59076672300); Abhishek, S. (57205017146); Anjali, T. (57195522716)
Title: Enhancing Veracity: Empirical Evaluation of Fake News Detection Techniques
Source title: Procedia Computer Science
Abstract: The relentless surge in the dissemination of fabricated news articles and misleading information poses a substantial threat to the veracity of information, trust in media sources, and the very foundations of democratic processes. In the contemporary landscape of information dissemination, the rampant propagation of false and misleading information has emerged as a paramount concern for both individuals and society at large. Consequently, the development of robust and efficient detection mechanisms has taken on a pivotal role in contemporary information ecosystems. The methodology employed encompasses three pivotal stages: initial data preprocessing, subsequent feature extraction involving the utilization of TF-IDF and Count Vectorization, and eventual classification that draws upon a diverse array of machine learning classifiers, in addition to deep learning models like Recurrent Neural Networks (RNN) and BERT networks. On a carefully selected dataset of instances of fake news, these models underwent rigorous testing and training.This research greatly aids in the continuous battle against disinformation by offering a methodical framework for identifying fake news. It also helps people and organisations make better decisions by shedding light on the relative merits of various deep learning and machine learning methods in this intricate and crucial context.. © 2024 The Authors. Published by Elsevier B.V.
Author Keywords: BERT; Data pre-processing; Deep Learning; Fake news; Feature extraction; Machine Learning; TF-IDF Vectorizer
Open Access: All Open Access; Gold Open Access

Authors: Rathod N., Mr.; Ramteke P.
Author full names: Rathod, Nachiket (58810859500); Ramteke, Prabhakar (57485314600)
Title: Multimodal Misinformation Mitigation using Convolutional and Knowledge Transfer Learning Approach
Source title: Proceedings - 2024 3rd International Conference on Sentiment Analysis and Deep Learning, ICSADL 2024
Abstract: In the era of information proliferation and digital media, the battle against the spread of misinformation has evolved into a critical challenge. This work presents an inclusive exploration of the pinnacle in misinformation mitigation, employing a multimodal method that integrates textual and visual data. Advanced techniques in knowledge transfer learning are used to develop and evaluate models for Misinformation detection based on textual content, images, and their fusion. DistilFND, a distillation of diverse models specialized in different modalities, is a focal point of proposed research. The paper involves a systematic analysis of training and testing these models on a shared dataset, enabling a comparison of their performance and the provision of insightful evaluations. Cohen's Kappa scores and ROC-AUC scores are also computed to gauge the models' efficacy. This extensive study marks a significant advance in misinformation mitigation, with knowledge transfer learning and multimodal fusion serving as pivotal elements of progress. By means of a sequence of detailed experiments and evaluation metrics, this work enhances to an improved understanding of how knowledge transfer learning, multimodal fusion, and pinnacle models can boost the correctness of Misinformation detection. The results and insights in this work aid the ongoing efforts to combat the detrimental impacts of misinformation in the digital sphere. © 2024 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Convolutional Neural Networks; Deep Learning; Fake News Detection; Knowledge Transfer Learning; Misinformation Mitigation; Multimodal; Neural Network Architecture

Authors: Zhao J.H.S.; Al-Dala’in T.
Author full names: Zhao, Justin Hui San (58485444100); Al-Dala’in, Thair (57201446905)
Title: The Hybrid Model Combination of Deep Learning Techniques, CNN-LSTM, BERT, Feature Selection, and Stop Words to Prevent Fake News
Source title: Lecture Notes in Networks and Systems
Abstract: Deep learning is a powerful and revolutionary subset of machine learning that involves training artificial neural networks to recognise patterns and predict outcomes with incredible accuracy. These neural networks are designed to mimic the human brain’s structure and can learn and improve over time through exposure to new data. This research uses other researchers’ conclusions to apply an encoding architecture to CNN-LSTM by utilising BERT. It is essential to conduct this research as it may result in the newest state-of-the-art technique for preventing fake news. It allows us to protect future generations, including adults and children, from fake news. The unique aspects of the proposed methodology and critical findings incorporate feature selection, stop words, and BERT as the encoder for CNN-LSTM. This research contributes to the field of fake news detection through the novel contribution of proposing BERT to be used as the encoder for CNN-LSTM, along with the implementation of Feature Selection and Stop Words. © The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG 2024.
Author Keywords: Bidirectional Encoder Representation from Transformers (BERT); Bidirectional Long short-term Memory (BILSTM); Convolution Neural Network (CNN); Long short-term Memory (LSTM); Term Frequency Inverse Document Frequency (TFIDF)

Authors: Kamble R.A.; Pareek V.; Jain T.
Author full names: Kamble, Riya Ajay (59172000600); Pareek, Varda (59384114200); Jain, Tarun (56375628900)
Title: Fake News Detection Using Machine Learning and Deep Learning
Source title: 2024 IEEE International Conference on Smart Power Control and Renewable Energy, ICSPCRE 2024
Abstract: In recent times, due to advancements in technology, news can be shared or received from one end of the world to another in a matter of seconds. However, such news is often not checked to see if it's true, which can lead to spreading false information. The spreading of misinformation can lead to distress and unease in public. It not only influences public opinion but also tarnishes the reputation of organizations, individuals, and societies. It can also lead to panic and unrest in public. For such reasons, it is necessary to verify the authenticity of news. This research paper aims to detect fake news with greater precision and accuracy using machine learning techniques. It uses various machine learning algorithms like Random Forest (RF), Support Vector Machine (SVM), and deep learning techniques like GloVe, (Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers) BERT. The highest accuracy is 98.95% which is achieved using BERT. © 2024 IEEE.
Author Keywords: BERT; Decision Tree; Machine Learning Algorithms; Natural Language Processing; Random Forest classifier; XGBoost

Title: International Conference on Recent Evolutions in Energy, Drives and E-Vehicles, REED-EV 2022

The topics include: Comparative Analysis of Mobile Substation; solar Photovoltaic Technology and Future Trends; Crop Leaf Disease Detection Using DCCN; Extraction of Seven Parameters of Double Diode Model Using Analytical and Optimization Method with RTC FRANCE PV Module Manufacturing Data; ioT in Agriculture: A Review; Development and Characterization of Electrode Using PAN/TiO2 Nanofibers to Improve the Battery Capacity; Enhancement of Power Quality of PV-Interfaced Distribution System Using Adaptive Backpropagation; Power Quality Improvement in a Transmission System Using (Series-Active Filter or DVR); breast Cancer Detection Using Deep Learning and Thermal Images; a Harmonic Current Compensation on a Grid-Connected Electric Vehicle; application of Electro-Mechanical Kinetic Energy Regenerative System and E-Lock Differential for an Electric Vehicle: A Review; challenges and Future Scope in Fake News Detection: A Survey; a Novel Analysis of Urban and Rural Thermal Comfort Levels as a Futuristic Human Dwelling Strategy; a Survey on Performance of Broadcasting Protocol for Ad hoc and Sensor Network; wheelchair Control Using IoT and Fall Detection Mechanism; modeling and Simulation of a Distributed Generation System for Power Quality Assessment; A Comprehensive PVsyst Design for a College Campus in Baghdad; Control of VSI in Microgrid Using Improved Particle Swarm Optimization; Emmet Territory Optimization Algorithm for Reduction of Pilot Contamination in Massive MIMO Systems; Assessment of FSPV-Grid System for Electrification of Industrial Sections with Shrinking Derating Factor; Modeling and Speed Control of DC Motor; PV-STATCOM in Distribution System.

Authors: Mallick C.; Mishra S.; Giri P.K.; Paikaray B.K.
Author full names: Mallick, Chandrakant (57191575045); Mishra, Sarojananda (55554581300); Giri, Parimal Kumar (57198354190); Paikaray, Bijay Kumar (56899181200)
Title: A metaheuristic optimisation-based deep learning model for fake news detection in online social networks
Source title: International Journal of Electronic Security and Digital Forensics
Abstract: The spread of fake news has become a societal problem. Most often, fake news spreads faster than real news and misleads society. Many works have been proposed in the literature using machine learning techniques to detect fake news, but developing a faster and more efficient model is still a challenging issue. Taking advantage of the deep neural network features of long- and short-term memory (LSTM) and metaheuristic optimisation algorithms, this paper proposes a Salp swarm algorithm-based optimised LSTM model to efficiently classify fake and real news in online social networks. To figure out the superiority of the model, it is experimentally demonstrated that the proposed model outperforms the LSTM optimised with other traditional optimisations. We tested the efficiency of the models on three datasets: the LIAR benchmark dataset, the ISOT dataset, and the news regarding the COVID-19 pandemic, and obtained accuracy of 97.89%, 86.49%, and 99.71%, respectively. Copyright © 2024 Inderscience Enterprises Ltd.
Author Keywords: BERT; deep learning; fake news; LSTM; optimisation; social network

Authors: Nair V.; Pareek D.J.; Bhatt S.
Author full names: Nair, Vinita (58450836800); Pareek, Dr. Jyoti (59179707200); Bhatt, Sanskruti (59179562000)
Title: A Knowledge-Based Deep Learning Approach for Automatic Fake News Detection using BERT on Twitter
Source title: Procedia Computer Science
Abstract: Fake news generation and propagation is a major challenge of the digital age, resulting in various social impacts namely bandwagon, validity, echo chamber effects, deceiving the public with spams, misinformation, malicious content and many more. The widespread proliferation of fake news not only fosters misinformation but also undermines the credibility of news sources. The veracity of the information is a major concern at all the stages of generation, publication, and propagation. To comprehend the critical need for addressing this pervasive problem, this research paper presents a framework for automatic detection of fake news using a knowledge-based approach. An automatic fact checking mechanism is applied using concepts of Information Retrieval (IR), Natural Language Processing (NLP) and Graph theory. The knowledge base is generated using Twitter dataset, which basically contains four attributes: Subject-Predicate-Object (SPO) triplet, SPO sentiment polarity, SPO occurrence, and topic modeling. These attributes serve as pivotal indicators for the development of a knowledge base, subsequently employed to detect prevalent patterns and traits linked to deceptive or false information. We have employed Named Entity Recognition (NER) model to extract SPO triples and Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA) for topic modeling, thereby contributing to knowledge base generation. To evaluate the efficacy and efficiency of our proposed model, we utilize deep learning algorithms like RNN, GRU, LSTM, GPT-3 and BERT Transformer providing an acceptable level of accuracy. This research paper delivers valuable insights into addressing the proliferation of fake news on Twitter, employing data-driven approaches and advanced deep learning algorithms. © 2024 Elsevier B.V.. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: BERT Transformer; Deep learning algorithms; Fake news; Knowledge-based; sentiment polarity; SPO triple; topic modeling; Twitter
Open Access: All Open Access; Gold Open Access

Authors: Benaouda W.; Ouamour S.; Sayoud H.
Author full names: Benaouda, Walid (58882883400); Ouamour, Siham (26029519100); Sayoud, Halim (26029630700)
Title: Comparison of CNN Model with Different Machine Learning Models for Fake News Detection
Source title: Proceedings - ECTE-Tech 2024: International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Telecommunication, and Energy Technologies
Abstract: Fake news continues to be a critical issue in today's era for any citizen concerned about political integrity and the state of governance. The use of internet has experienced exponential growth, leading to an increase in fake news or misinformation. This misinformation negatively impacts individuals and societies. Therefore, It is critical to stop and identify fake news. In this paper, we develop a model based on convolutional neural networks for detecting fake news. We also compare our proposed model with eight other machine learning models using various metrics. Our model achieved an accuracy of 98.52%, outperforming all other models, with support vector machine (SVM) proving to be the best among the machine learning models used. ©2024 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Classification; Deep learning; Fake news; Machine learning; Natural Language Processing; TF-IDF

Authors: Aggarwal N.; Kumar S.
Author full names: Aggarwal, Nikhil (57666757600); Kumar, Siddharth (58071245200)
Title: An Optimized TF-IDF Features based Deep Learning Enabled Automated Fake News Detection Scheme
Source title: 2024 Asia Pacific Conference on Innovation in Technology, APCIT 2024
Abstract: People are exposed to a variety of false news and disinformation because of the continuously changing social media landscape and the various sources of information used by news organizations and production companies. We are now conducting research to find useful techniques to detect this false news, and the designed system is known as deep learning enabled an automated Fake News Detection (FND) system. The categorization or identification of fake news in online social media platforms has drawn more interest from the machine learning community. Misleading news refers to news stories that purposefully mislead readers by disseminating false information. In this post, we suggest a solution for social media platforms that automatically detects bogus news. Pre-processing, extraction of features, feature optimization, and classification were the four processes employed by the suggested system. Here, the concept of Term Frequency-Inverted Document Frequency (TF-IDF)-based approach is used as the feature extraction scheme and the extracted features are optimized using the concept of swarm-based Artificial Bee Colony (ABC) by designing an appropriate and novel fitness/objective function. ABC creates two categories of news, first as Fake and second as Real. Based on these categories, further Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) is used to train the FND model. To verify the effectiveness of the suggested FND model, parameters like Precision, Recall, and F-measure (PRF) with Accuracy are computed. Finally, I assess how the suggested FND system performs in comparison to current models. to validate the performance in terms of PRF and we observed that the FND system got better results with accuracy of 99% for most of the cases. © 2024 IEEE.
Author Keywords: ABC; CNN; Fake News Analysis; Internet; Social-Media; TF-IDF Feature Extraction

Title: 2nd International Conference on Self Sustainable Artificial Intelligence Systems, ICSSAS 2024 - Proceedings
Source title: 2nd International Conference on Self Sustainable Artificial Intelligence Systems, ICSSAS 2024 - Proceedings
Abstract: The proceedings contain 265 papers. The topics discussed include: feature integration-based residual deep learning model for fake news detection using multimodal data sources; a novel hybrid TLBO-RAT algorithm for optimal and cost-effective power generation scheduling; classifying brain tumors using advanced machine learning techniques: a comprehensive comparative analysis; revolutionizing assessment: AI-powered evaluation with RAG and LLM technologies; scene-based event detection using Grey Wolf optimization enabled BiLSTM classification; an attention-based rainfall prediction system using LSTM model and convolutional block module; rice leaf disease detection using fusion optimization; machine learning techniques for disease prediction in rice plant; TrackTrust: revolutionizing supply chain management through blockchain integration; enhancing robust object detection in weather-impacted environments using deep learning techniques; and review of battery thermal management system: role of PCM in thermal management.

Authors: Angizeh L.B.; Keyvanpour M.R.
Author full names: Angizeh, Leila Behboudi (59151363900); Keyvanpour, Mohammad Reza (24476189600)
Title: Detecting Fake News using Advanced Language Models: BERT and RoBERTa
Source title: 2024 10th International Conference on Web Research, ICWR 2024
Abstract: The fake news story refers to information falsified or made up to manipulate or deceive the public. It is a serious issue that undermines the credibility of information sources and influences public opinion, discourse, and important decisions and outcomes. The content and source of news articles and stories must be considered when identifying and classifying fake news. Detecting fake news is an important and active research area with many potential applications and implications for society. Many challenges are involved in determining whether a news article is authentic. Several deep learning models that employ natural language processing (NLP) have shown excellent results in detecting fake news. To assess the truthfulness of news articles, our methodology is based on state-of-the-art language models based on transformers. Bidirectional Encoder Representation from Transformers (BERT) and Robustly Optimized BERT Technique (RoBERTa) is one of the most advanced models. Our findings reveal that the BERT model achieved an accuracy of 64%, while the RoBERTa model slightly outperformed it with an accuracy of 66%. These results are particularly significant when compared to similar research in this domain, which reported a maximum accuracy of 62% for both models on Liar dataset.  © 2024 IEEE.
Author Keywords: BERT; Deep Learning; Fake News; Fake News Detection; Natural Language Processing; Roberta

Authors: Osama Md.; Ahmed K.; Taher H.M.A.; Hossain J.; Ahsan S.; Hoque M.M.
Author full names: Osama, Md. (58886980000); Ahmed, Kawsar (58886851700); Taher, Hasan Mesbaul Ali (58886889100); Hossain, Jawad (58886821900); Ahsan, Shawly (58930269300); Hoque, Mohammed Moshiul (55436576000)
Title: CUET_NLP_GoodFellows@DravidianLangTech EACL2024: A Transformer-Based Approach for Detecting Fake News in Dravidian Languages
Source title: DravidianLangTech 2024 - 4th Workshop on Speech, Vision, and Language Technologies for Dravidian Languages, Proceedings of the Workshop
Abstract: In this modern era, many people have been using Facebook and Twitter, leading to increased information sharing and communication. However, a considerable amount of information on these platforms is misleading or intentionally crafted to deceive users, which is often termed as fake news. A shared task on fake news detection in Malayalam organized by DravidianLangTech@EACL 2024 allowed us for addressing the challenge of distinguishing between original and fake news content in the Malayalam language. Our approach involves creating an intelligent framework to categorize text as either fake or original. We experimented with various machine learning models, including Logistic Regression, Decision Tree, Random Forest, Multinomial Naive Bayes, SVM, and SGD, and various deep learning models, including CNN, BiLSTM, and BiLSTM + Attention. We also explored Indic-BERT, MuRIL, XLM-R, and m-BERT for transformer-based approaches. Notably, our most successful model, m-BERT, achieved a macro F1 score of 0.85 and ranked 4th in the shared task. This research contributes to combating misinformation on social media news, offering an effective solution to classify content accurately. © 2024 Association for Computational Linguistics.

Authors: Moalla H.; Abid H.; Sallami D.; Aïmeur E.; Hamed B.B.
Author full names: Moalla, Hounaida (55811724500); Abid, Hana (59465473400); Sallami, Dorsaf (57482014000); Aïmeur, Esma (6603130580); Hamed, Bassem Ben (22941131400)
Title: Exploring the Power of Dual Deep Learning for Fake News Detection
Source title: Informatica (Slovenia)
Abstract: The rise of social media has intensified the spread of fake news, a problem further exacerbated by generative artificial intelligence (AI). Hence, the need for improved detection of both human-created and AI-generated fake news using advanced AI models is critical. This paper proposes a survey to assess knowledge and attitudes towards news and AI, combining demographic data, personality traits, and the ability to distinguish between real and AI-generated news. Additionally, we create a new dataset, ERAF-News, containing real, fake, AI-generated true, and AI-generated fake news. To classify different types of news, we developed a dual-stream transformer model, DuSTraMo. This model leverages the capabilities of two parallel transformers to enhance the accuracy of news classification. The survey, involving 83 participants from 9 countries, revealed that respondents struggle to differentiate human-generated from AI-generated news. Notably, BERT outperformed GPT-2 and BART in generating realistic text, and RoBERTa and DistilBERT achieved over 98% accuracy in fake news classification. Dual-GPT models also showed high accuracy. This study underscores the effectiveness of the DuSTraMo model and the ERAF-News dataset in enhancing the detection of both human-created and AI-generated fake news. The findings highlight the increasing dominance of AI in this domain and the pressing need for advanced methods to combat fake news. Additionally, a survey examining users’ responses to fake news reveals a concerning inability to accurately identify false information. © 2024 Slovene Society Informatika. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: big five; deep learning; detection; Fake news; generative artificial intelligence; personality traits; SEM; survey; transformers
Open Access: All Open Access; Gold Open Access

Authors: Rana T.; Saraswat D.; Gaind A.; Singla R.; Chhabra A.
Author full names: Rana, Tushar (57215122136); Saraswat, Darshan (58781220500); Gaind, Akul (58781385800); Singla, Rhythem (58781318400); Chhabra, Amit (57539985500)
Title: A BERT Classifier Approach for Evaluation of Fake News Dissemination
Source title: Communications in Computer and Information Science
Abstract: The intake of information via media has changed from newspapers to social networking sites as technology has evolved. Accessibility and availability are two important aspects that have led to this trend in media usage. Users share thousands of posts, articles, and videos as the internet penetration grows. These postings are done on a variety of social networking sites such as Facebook, Instagram, YouTube, Twitter, and others. It is now widely acknowledged that disinformation may often create tensions and has a substantial impact in the country. Stemming the tide of false news articles via social networking sites and the Internet is critical. This problem has indeed been handled in this study using various algorithmic approaches that could help us to control this type of hazardous thing. Including the findings, a contrast of how various classification functions are offered. This article gives a thorough assessment of numerous fake news detection strategies employed by various other authors, databases they had engaged with, and the multiple analytical people were using to evaluate the effectiveness of their respective algorithms. This research analyses the troubles and challenges of detecting this type of news. This article examines documents from 2017 through 2022, as well as various fake news detecting tools. This study provides a complete evaluation of present and past studies on false news recognition leveraging various ML and DL models. In this research work, BERT Classifier has been used which uses a deep learning technique and has the highest accuracy of all the methods described. © The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG 2024.
Author Keywords: and classification models; Artificial Intelligence; BERT; Deep learning; Fake news; Machine learning; Regression

Authors: Devarajan G.G.; Nagarajan S.M.; Amanullah S.I.; Mary S.A.S.A.; Bashir A.K.
Author full names: Devarajan, Ganesh Gopal (57217071976); Nagarajan, Senthil Murugan (57213581844); Amanullah, Sardar Irfanullah (58156527300); Mary, S. A. Sahaaya Arul (25636447400); Bashir, Ali Kashif (57193954653)
Title: AI-Assisted Deep NLP-Based Approach for Prediction of Fake News from Social Media Users
Source title: IEEE Transactions on Computational Social Systems
Abstract: Social networking websites are now considered to be the best platforms for the dissemination of news articles. However, information sharing in social media platforms leads to explosion of fake news. Traditional detection methods were focusing on content analysis, while the current researchers examining social features of the news. In this work, we proposed a novel artificial intelligence (AI)-assisted fake news detection with deep natural language processing (NLP) model. The proposed work is characterized in four layers: publisher layer, social media networking layer, enabled edge layer, and cloud layer. In this work, four steps were carried out: 1) data acquisition; 2) information retrieval (IR); 3) NLP-based data processing and feature extraction; and 4) deep learning-based classification model that classifies news articles as fake or real using credibility score of publishers, users, messages, headlines, and so on. Three datasets, such as Buzzface, FakeNewsNet, and Twitter, were used for evaluation of the proposed model, and simulation results were computed. This proposed model obtained an average accuracy of 99.72% and an F1 score of 98.33%, which outperforms other existing methods. © 2014 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Artificial intelligence (AI); deep learning; fake news; information retrieval (IR); natural language processing (NLP)

Authors: Dahou A.H.; Cheragui M.A.; Abdedaiem A.; Mathiak B.
Author full names: Dahou, Abdelhalim Hafedh (57889862400); Cheragui, Mohamed Amine (55994821300); Abdedaiem, Amin (58634405200); Mathiak, Brigitte (9942026800)
Title: Enhancing Model Performance through Translation-based Data Augmentation in the context of Fake News Detection
Source title: Procedia Computer Science
Abstract: The rapid development of social media in recent years has encouraged the sharing of vast amounts of data and the propagation of fake news. This has pushed the scientific community to focus on this phenomenon, particularly those working on natural language processing, by developing detection tools to combat fake news. At the same time, most studies have focused on languages with a high resource content (corpus). This paper aims to shed light on low-resource languages, particularly the Algerian dialect, through an experimental study with two objectives. The first one is to verify if the automatic translation from Modern Standard Arabic (MSA) to the Algerian dialect can be considered an approach to increase the resources in the Algerian dialect, especially with the rise of large language models (LLMs). The second is to verify the impact of the translation-based data augmentation method on fake news detection by using transformer-based Arabic pre-trained models in different data augmentation configurations. We have discovered that LLMs can generate translations that closely resemble human translations. In this study, we demonstrate that data augmentation can result in saturation and a decline in model performance due to the introduction of noise and variations in writing styles. © 2024 The Authors. Published by Elsevier B.V.
Author Keywords: Algerian Dialect; Data Augmentation; Deep Learning; Fake News; Machine Translation
Open Access: All Open Access; Gold Open Access

Authors: Mondal P.K.; Khan S.S.; Rana M.M.; Ramit S.S.; Sattar A.; Rahman M.S.
Author full names: Mondal, Pronoy Kumar (59459422900); Khan, Sadman Sadik (59194745400); Rana, Md. Masud (59436542300); Ramit, Shahriar Sultan (59189019200); Sattar, Abdus (57209096022); Rahman, Md. Sadekur (57212184235)
Title: Breaking the Fake News Barrier: Deep Learning Approaches in Bangla Language
Source title: 2024 15th International Conference on Computing Communication and Networking Technologies, ICCCNT 2024
Abstract: The rapid development of digital stages has greatly compounded the dispersal of untrue data, dissolving certainty and judgment in society, especially among the Bengalispeaking community. Our ponder addresses this critical issue by presenting an interesting strategy that utilizes a profound learning innovation, particularly the Gated Repetitive Unit (GRU), to recognize fake news within the Bangla dialect. The strategy of our proposed work incorporates intensive information preprocessing, which includes lemmatization, tokenization, and tending to course awkward nature by oversampling. This comes about in a dataset containing 58,478 passages. We appreciate the creation of a demonstration based on GRU (Gated Repetitive Unit) that illustrates remarkable execution with a noteworthy precision rate of 94%. This ponder gives an intensive clarification of the methods included in planning the information, selecting the show, preparing it, and assessing its execution. The performance of the model is investigated by reliable metrics like precision, recall, F1 score, and accuracy. The commitment of the work incorporates making a huge fake news dataset in Bangla and a demonstration that has outperformed other Bangla fake news location models. © 2024 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Bangla Fake News Detection; Bangla Text Classification; Deep Learning; Gated Recurrent Unit (GRU); Imbalanced Dataset; Oversampling

Authors: Esan A.; Abodunrin O.; Sobowale A.; Adeyanju I.; Okomba N.; Omodunbi B.; Adebiyi T.; Jooda J.; Abdul-Hameed T.; Asaolu O.
Author full names: Esan, Adebimpe (56801688600); Abodunrin, Olayinka (58837310800); Sobowale, Adedayo (57219258596); Adeyanju, Ibrahim (35104383100); Okomba, Nnamdi (57217022149); Omodunbi, Bolaji (57204627399); Adebiyi, Tomilayo (58839069300); Jooda, Janet (58701940000); Abdul-Hameed, Taofeek (58838570100); Asaolu, Opeyemi (58838823500)
Title: Long-Short-Term Memory Model for Fake News Detection in Nigeria
Source title: Ianna Journal of Interdisciplinary Studies
Abstract: Background: The advent of technology allows information to be passed through the Internet at a breakneck speed and enables the involvement of many individuals in the use of different social media platforms. Propagation of fake news through the Internet has become rampant due to digitalisation, and the spread of fake news can cause irreparable damage to the victims. The conventional approach to fake news detection is time-consuming, hence introducing fake news detection systems. Existing fake news detection systems have yielded low accuracy and are unsuitable in Nigeria. Objective: This research aims to design and implement a framework for fake news detection using the Long-Short Term Memory (LSTM) model. Methodology: The dataset for the model was obtained from Nigerian dailies and Kaggle and pre-processed by removing punctuation marks and stop words, stemming, tokenisation and one hot representation. Feature extraction was done on the datasets to remove outliers. The locally acquired dataset from Nigeria was balanced using Synthetic Minority Oversampling Techniques (SMOTE) Long-Short Term Memory (LSTM), a variant of Recurrent Neural Network (RNN)-which solved the problem of losing gained knowledge and information over a long period faced by RNN-was used as the detection model This model was implemented using Python 3.9. The model detected fake news by classifying real and fake news approaches. The dataset was fed into the model, and the model classified them as either fake or real news by processing the dataset through input and hidden layers of varying numbers of neurons. accuracy F1 score and detection time were used as the evaluation metrics. The results were then compared to some selected machine learning models and a hybrid of convolutional neural networks and long short-term memory models (CNN-LSTM). Results: The result shows that the LSTM model on a balanced dataset performed best as the two news classes were accurately classified, giving an average detection accuracy of 92.86%, which took the model 0.42 seconds to detect whether news was real or fake. Also, 87.50% average detection accuracy was obtained from an imbalanced dataset. Compared to other machine learning models, SVM and CNN-LSTM gave 81.25% accuracy for imbalanced datasets and 82.14% and 78.57% for balanced datasets, respectively. Conclusion: The outcome of this research shows that the deep learning approach outperformed some machine learning models for fake news detection in terms of performance accuracy. Unique contribution: This work has contributed knowledge by employing an LSTM model for detecting Nigerian fake news using an indigenous dataset. Key Recommendation: Future research should increase the data size of indigenous datasets for fake news detection to achieve improved accuracy. © 2023, University of Nigeria Department of Mass Communication. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: accuracy; deep learning; detection; Fake news; model; SMOTE

Authors: Maity K.; Bhattacharya S.; Phosit S.; Kongsamlit S.; Saha S.; Pasupa K.
Author full names: Maity, Krishanu (57202444455); Bhattacharya, Shaubhik (58312193400); Phosit, Salisa (58654411000); Kongsamlit, Sawarod (58654312800); Saha, Sriparna (17435835500); Pasupa, Kitsuchart (13204394500)
Title: HANCaps: A Two-Channel Deep Learning Framework for Fake News Detection in Thai
Source title: Communications in Computer and Information Science
Abstract: The rapid advancement of internet technology, widespread smartphone usage, and the rise of social media platforms have drastically transformed the global communication landscape. These developments have resulted in both positive and negative consequences. On the one hand, they have facilitated the dissemination of information, connecting individuals across vast distances and fostering diverse perspectives. On the other hand, the ease of access to online platforms has led to the proliferation of misinformation, often in the form of fake news. Detecting and combatting fake news has become crucial to mitigate its adverse effects on society. This paper presents an investigation into fake news detection in the Thai language. It addresses current limitations in this domain by proposing a novel two-channel deep learning model named HANCaps, which integrates BERT and FastText embeddings with a hierarchical attention network and capsule network. The HANCaps model utilizes the BERT language model as one channel input, while the other channel incorporates pre-trained FastText embeddings. The proposed model undergoes evaluation using a benchmark Thai fake news dataset, and extensive experimentation demonstrates that HANCaps outperforms state-of-the-art methods by up to 3.28% in terms of F1 score, showcasing its superior performance. © 2024, The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Singapore Pte Ltd.
Author Keywords: Capsule Network; Fake News; Hierarchical Attention Network; Thai

Authors: Hashmi E.; Yayilgan S.Y.; Yamin M.M.; Ali S.; Abomhara M.
Author full names: Hashmi, Ehtesham (58922146700); Yayilgan, Sule Yildirim (57204767591); Yamin, Muhammad Mudassar (57205121104); Ali, Subhan (58190535600); Abomhara, Mohamed (57997898500)
Title: Advancing Fake News Detection: Hybrid Deep Learning With FastText and Explainable AI
Source title: IEEE Access
Abstract: The widespread propagation of misinformation on social media platforms poses a significant concern, prompting substantial endeavors within the research community to develop robust detection solutions. Individuals often place unwavering trust in social networks, often without discerning the origins and authenticity of the information disseminated through these platforms. Hence, the identification of media-rich fake news necessitates an approach that adeptly leverages multimedia elements and effectively enhances detection accuracy. The ever-changing nature of cyberspace highlights the need for measures that may effectively resist the spread of media-rich fake news while protecting the integrity of information systems. This study introduces a robust approach for fake news detection, utilizing three publicly available datasets: WELFake, FakeNewsNet, and FakeNewsPrediction. We integrated FastText word embeddings with various Machine Learning and Deep Learning methods, further refining these algorithms with regularization and hyperparameter optimization to mitigate overfitting and promote model generalization. Notably, a hybrid model combining Convolutional Neural Networks and Long Short-Term Memory, enriched with FastText embeddings, surpassed other techniques in classification performance across all datasets, registering accuracy and F1-scores of 0.99, 0.97, and 0.99, respectively. Additionally, we utilized state-of-the-art transformer-based models such as BERT, XLNet, and RoBERTa, enhancing them through hyperparameter adjustments. These transformer models, surpassing traditional RNN-based frameworks, excel in managing syntactic nuances, thus aiding in semantic interpretation. In the concluding phase, explainable AI modeling was employed using Local Interpretable Model-Agnostic Explanations, and Latent Dirichlet Allocation to gain deeper insights into the model's decision-making process. © 2013 IEEE.
Author Keywords: deep learning; Fake news; interpretability modeling; machine learning; transformers; word embeddings
Open Access: All Open Access; Gold Open Access

Authors: Bhargavi S.G.V.; Kumar P.S.; Mounika N.; Govardhan A.; Suvarna B.; Likhita P.
Author full names: Bhargavi, Sanku Ganga Veera (58127566400); Kumar, P. Siva (59139956400); Mounika, N. (59915070100); Govardhan, Annamnedi (59258879000); Suvarna, Barre (59258813000); Likhita, Pampana (59258685800)
Title: An Ensemble Method for Encountering Bogus News in Social Media: A Review
Source title: Proceedings - 2024 International Conference on Social and Sustainable Innovations in Technology and Engineering, SASI-ITE 2024
Abstract: Rapid spread of the Internet Fake news travels from multiple sources to consumers via a complex ecology of websites, social media, and bots, and social media also spreads leading to changes in people's news consumption. from multiple sources Most individuals spread bogus news to achieve popularity on social networks. This article describes an innovative hybrid fake news detection system that combines convolutional neural networks (CNN), language networks, and knowledge-based networks. We measured model performance using F1 score, precision, accuracy, and recall. Most machine learning algorithms can recognize bogus news on social media One of the most well-liked machine-learning methods for identifying false news is the use of Naive Bayes, Support Vector Machines (SVM), and neural networks. Some of the most prevalent characteristics that may be used to detect false news include the source of the news, the language utilized, and the words used. The best technique to recognize false news depends on the unique dataset and application. A summary is a brief overview of the system, which then utilizes machine learning to identify news pieces as false or legitimate. This study is expected to be more accurate than standard ways of identifying false news. It is used to extract information from news items and the apply machine learning to categorize them as false or authentic.  © 2024 IEEE.
Author Keywords: CNN; Deep Learning; Fake News; Machine Learning; NLP; Preprocessing; Word Embedding

Authors: Ladouceur R.; Hassan A.; Mejri M.; Jaafar F.
Author full names: Ladouceur, Rachel (58646807600); Hassan, Abubakr (59364303700); Mejri, Mohamed (6602661138); Jaafar, Fehmi (54684236700)
Title: Can Deep Learning Detect Fake News Better when Adding Context Features?
Source title: Proceedings of the 2024 IEEE International Conference on Cyber Security and Resilience, CSR 2024
Abstract: Fake news is increasing on social media and has huge negative impacts on society. To detect fake news, different approaches and algorithms have been studied. Recently, the use of deep learning algorithms has performed very well for fake news detection. Many researchers found the importance to add the context features to have better and a rapid detection. The current paper presents two algorithms, BERT and LSTM, for the classification of fake news, by using text and context features. Moreover, we add XAI solution that determines which context features have contributed the most to the classification of fake news. We have trained our model with an extraction of 5,000 news from the COVID-19 dataset. Our result shows that BERT performs better by 2.37% than LSTM by analyzing only the content and performs better by 2.24% by analyzing both, the content and the context. Finally, SHAP is used to explain fake news by highlighting the most relevant attributes that have helped to the classification of news. © 2024 IEEE.
Author Keywords: deep learning; Fake news; network analysis; XAI

Authors: Khattab N.; Al-Qerem A.; Nashwan S.; Jebreen I.; Rajab M.; Alauthman M.; Jeadi M.; Elrashidi A.
Author full names: Khattab, Nada (59388158600); Al-Qerem, Ahmad (35365854400); Nashwan, Shadi (24465221400); Jebreen, Issam (55960428300); Rajab, Mohammed (59670016100); Alauthman, Mohammad (57202469802); Jeadi, Mohammad (59669557900); Elrashidi, Ali (55657725800)
Title: Unveiling Deception: Different Strategies for Combatting Arabic Fake News
Source title: 2024 25th International Arab Conference on Information Technology, ACIT 2024
Abstract: the proliferation of fake news has become a widespread problem in the contemporary era of information, posing possible harm to public discussions, political stability, and community confidence. To tackle this difficulty, it is necessary to develop strong and effective detection methods that can accurately recognize misinformation in several languages, including Arabic. The aim of this study is to create and assess different models specifically designed for the identification of fake news in Arabic language.Several of deep Learning models like Recurrent Neural Networks (RNN), Long short-term memory (LSTM), Bidirectional long short term memory (Bi-LSTM) and convolutional neural network (CNN) are used in this study. On the other hand, some of the traditional machine learning models like k-nearest neighbors (KNN), Random Forests (RF), Extreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost), decision tree (DT) and multi-layer perceptron (MLP) are also used. Also, transformers, like Generative pre-trained Transformer 3 (Gpt-3) and Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers (BERT), are used as a feature extraction to convert text into numerical representation and assign different number to each token. All of these models were used in evaluation which of them is the best model in the process of fake news detection for the Arabic Language Dataset.The findings demonstrate strong performance across deep learning models, with CNN-LSTM, Bi-LSTM and CNN-Bi-LSTM exhibiting the best accuracy rates of 93.2% ,92.6%, 93.6% respectively. The LSTM model achieves a moderate accuracy of 87.4%, whilst the RNN model demonstrates a more modest accuracy of 56.8%. The results emphasize the capability of deep learning methods in reducing the dissemination of fake information in Arabic-language datasets. © 2024 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Arabic Fake News; Bi-LSTM; Classification; Classifier; CNN-Bi-LSTM; Deep Learning; Features Extraction; GPT-3; LSTM; Machine Learning; Mining; RNN; Tokenization; Transformers

Title: 2nd International Conference on Deep Sciences for Computing and Communications, IconDeepCom 2023
Source title: Communications in Computer and Information Science
Abstract: The proceedings contain 82 papers. The special focus in this conference is on Deep Sciences for Computing and Communications. The topics include: Digital Identity System for Real World Asset Using Blockchain; blockchain-Driven Framework for Fake Product Detection; blockchain Powered Real-Estate Management System; a Block-Chain Based Decentralized Mechanism to Ensure the Security of Electronic Voting System Using Solidity Language; a Secure Persistent Health Care System Using Blockchain Smart Contract; multimodal Fake News Detection Using Deep Learning Techniques; maritime Human Drowning Detection Using Intelligent Deep Learning Algorithm; development of a Pothole Detection System Using Deep Learning Techniques and Depth Estimation; machine Learning and Deep Learning Algorithms for Breast Cancer Prediction; leaf Disease Detection Using Deep Learning Approach; Robust Traffic Sign Recognition Using CNN YOLOv5 Model; Fusion Emotion Prediction Using the CEFER Algorithm; performance Analysis of Various Machine Learning Techniques for Mental Health Tracking; Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) Detection Analysis Using Machine Learning; Revolutionizing MS Rehabilitation with Digital Twins and Machine Learning: A Promising Path to Precision Medicine; empirical Evaluation of Machine Learning Techniques for Car Price Prediction; water Quality Analysis Using Machine Learning Techniques; design and Development of Human Identification and Obstacle Detection System for Blind Using Machine Learning; effective Parkinson Disease Detection and Prediction Using Voting Classifier in Machine Learning; inflow and Infiltration Water Problem Detection Using Machine Learning; crop Recommendation and Production Prediction; a Comparison of Cox Model and Machine Learning Techniques in the High-Dimensional Survival Data; Smart Farming: Using IoT and AI to Improve Crop Yield in Aeroponics System.

Authors: Venkat R.S.; kuchipudi R.; rao K.G.; Srikanth G.; babu P.R.; Murthy T.S.; Kishore G.V.
Author full names: Venkat, R. Sai (57211159975); kuchipudi, Ramu (57192542112); rao, K. Gangadhara (56440191200); Srikanth, G. (59296424000); babu, Palamakula Ramesh (57193722789); Murthy, T. Satyanarayana (56041063200); Kishore, G. Venakata (59297037700)
Title: Face News Detection Using Machine Learning Techniques
Source title: Lecture Notes of the Institute for Computer Sciences, Social-Informatics and Telecommunications Engineering, LNICST
Abstract: Nowadays, most people are shifting to online news reading rather than traditional methods because of its convenience and low cost. So, the number of online users is increasing day by day, which is also increasing fake news across the internet. This fake news must be detected and removed from the internet before causing damage to the nation’s peace. Social media platforms use fake news recognition algorithms to detect and remove misinformation from their platforms. However, these algorithms can fail when they misidentify satirical or humorous content as fake news. News organizations use fake news recognition technology to fact-check articles and ensure the accuracy of their reporting. However, these algorithms may fail to detect more sophisticated forms of misinformation, such as deep fakes or highly persuasive disinformation campaigns, leading to the spread of false information. Existing framework contains three main modules: information retrieval, natural language processing, and machine learning. Also has two phases: the data collection phase and the machine learning model-building phase. In the data collection phase, we obtained a data set and analyzed the data using natural language processing techniques to extract good features from web data. A detailed survey on an automatic online fake news detection using machine learning techniques are elaborated. © ICST Institute for Computer Sciences, Social Informatics and Telecommunications Engineering 2024.
Author Keywords: deep learning; Fake News; learning; Machine Learning; optimization

Authors: Tabassum N.; Aodhora S.R.; Akter R.; Hossain J.; Ahsan S.; Hoque M.M.
Author full names: Tabassum, Nafisa (57719331100); Aodhora, Sumaiya Rahman (58977183600); Akter, Rowshon (55768240900); Hossain, Jawad (58886821900); Ahsan, Shawly (58930269300); Hoque, Mohammed Moshiul (55436576000)
Title: Punny_Punctuators@DravidianLangTech-EACL2024: Transformer-based Approach for Detection and Classification of Fake News in Malayalam Social Media Text
Source title: DravidianLangTech 2024 - 4th Workshop on Speech, Vision, and Language Technologies for Dravidian Languages, Proceedings of the Workshop
Abstract: The alarming rise of fake news on social media poses a significant threat to public discourse and decision-making. While automatic detection of fake news offers a promising solution, research in low-resource languages like Malayalam often falls behind due to limited data and tools. This paper presents the participation of team Punny_Punctuators in the Fake News Detection in Dravidian Languages shared task at DravidianLangTech@EACL 2024, addressing this gap. The shared task focuses on two subtasks: 1. classifying social media texts as original or fake, and 2. categorizing fake news into 5 categories. We experimented with various machine learning (ML), deep learning (DL) and transformer-based models as well as processing techniques such as transliteration. Malayalam-BERT achieved the best performance on both sub-tasks, which obtained us 2nd place with a macro f1-score of 0.87 for the subtask-1 and 11th place with a macro f1-score of 0.17 for the subtask-2. Our results highlight the potential of transformer models for low-resource languages in fake news detection and pave the way for further research in this crucial area. © 2024 Association for Computational Linguistics.

Authors: Sharma V.; Pateriya R.K.; Gupta R.K.; Dehalwar V.
Author full names: Sharma, Vaibhav (59988732500); Pateriya, R.K. (48761729000); Gupta, Rajeev Kumar (57211512980); Dehalwar, Vasudev (55578031000)
Title: Empowering Informed Citizens: A Hybrid Model for Local Language Fake News Detection
Source title: 2024 Asia Pacific Conference on Innovation in Technology, APCIT 2024
Abstract: In today's fast paced world of media and the internet, people are more connected, than ever before. Information can quickly spread across these platforms leading to the dissemination of news. Unfortunately, some of this information is false and misleading. The sharing of content often results in negative actions and outcomes with certain individuals intentionally causing chaos among the public. This research introduces a deep learning model that combines a convolutional neural network (CNN) and recurrent neural networks (RNN) for identifying fake news. The model was successfully tested on the CONSTRAINT2021 dataset achieving an F1 score of 89% surpassing standard methods.
